column1:
Some residents in Vernon township are still under a boil water advisory, after a water man break Monday night.

The 12-inch main broke at the intersection of the Mead Avenue bridge, Cussewago road, and Hank street.
It sent water rushing into a couple of nearby homes on Hank street, causing damage.
It also sent mud and debris onto nearby roads.
It took crews several hours to fix it, water was restored around 10:30 Monday evening.
About 25 homes are on a boil water advisory, that could be lifted on Thursday.

CHARLESTON, W.Va. -- The Department of Health and Human Resources has lifted the boil-water advisory for the Cow Town area of the Meadow Bridge Water system.Ravencliff-McGraws-Saulsville Public Service District has lifted the boil-water advisory issued for the following locations: McGraws -- from John McGraw school toward Saulsville, Saulsville, Keyrock, Twin Falls, Cabin Creek and New Richmond.West Virginia American Water has issued a boil-water advisory for approximately 30 Salt Rock customers for the streets of 6700-6100 of Blue Sulphur Road, from Big 7 Mile to and including Hall's Hill Road. The advisory follows a water main break. Customers in those areas should boil their water for at least one full minute prior to use until further notice.

Salt Rock Boil Water Advisory Issued
From Press Release

Salt Rock, W.Va.  – West Virginia American Water has issued a precautionary boil water advisory for approximately 30 customers for the streets of 6700-6100 of Blue Sulphur road from Big 7 Mile to and including Hall’s Hill Road . The advisory follows a water main break, which West Virginia American Water crews are working to repair as quickly as possible. Customers will be notified door-to-door.

Affected customers should boil their water before consumption until further notice. Boiling kills bacteria and other organisms that may be present in the water. Customers are asked to bring water used for drinking, cooking, bathing and brushing teeth to a full boil for a minimum of one minute, then cool before use.
West Virginia American Water also recommends the following steps:
* Throw away beverages and ice cubes if made with tap water
* Keep boiled water in the refrigerator for drinking
* Provide pets with boiled water after cooling
* Do not use home filtering devices in place of boiling or using bottled water

Grocery stores see boost in water sales, business returns to normal after weekend boil water advisory
Jeremy Arias | jarias@pennlive.com
Email the author | Follow on Twitter
on June 03, 2013 at 12:18 PM, updated June 03, 2013 at 2:57 PM
'title':'Grocery stores see boost in water sales, business returns to normal after weekend boil water advisory',
'desc': 'Businesses along the West Shore, like residents, relied on creative means to secure clean water.',

Businesses all along the West Shore are returning to normal after a boil water advisory for much of the area was lifted Monday after nearly two days.

Grocery stores and other bottled water dealers were reporting a notable bump in sales over the weekend, after a leak near the Silver Spring Square Shopping Center off Carlisle Pike sparked the Pennsylvania-American Water Co.'s concern about possible bacterial contamination in the immediate area.

As news of the advisory spread, residents and businesses from Silver Spring to Hampden, East Pennsboro and Lower Allen townships suddenly found themselves relying on what bottled water they could find — or a lengthy boiling process — to meet their needs.

The advisory was lifted around 6:30 a.m. Monday after two separate tests confirmed the water was safe, but it lasted long enough to bring residents out in droves to the local Giant grocery store at 310 East Penn Drive in Enola, a store manager said.

""Our warehouse stocks water pretty regularly so we were able to get some emergency deliveries in from Carlisle,"" said the manager, who was unable to provide his name due to company policy. ""So we had a limited selection for a while, but we ended up having plenty.""

Other stores, including the Target in the Silver Spring Square center, also noticed higher than average water sales, said Lee McCauslin, a store employee.

""Our gallon jugs were completely sold out, but we had enough to get through,"" he said.

While the Target itself did not close, two satellite restaurants inside the store closed shortly after the leak Saturday, McCauslin said.

""We did have to close the Pizza Hut and the Starbucks located in the store because they do use the water and they were telling us it wasn't safe,"" he said. ""They're still shut down today cleaning up and getting everything ready, but they should be open tomorrow.""

Other area restaurants utilized a number of ingenious contingency plans to continue seating customers during the advisory.

""We reopened Saturday night around 5 o'clock after having a few of our guys go out and pick up some bottled water,"" said Elliott Peters, a manager of the Olive Garden at 6520 Carlisle Pike. ""And we're open today, it's business as usual.""

Meanwhile, several employees from the Sakura Japanese Restaurant at 6499 Carlisle Pike found an even cheaper way to get clean water to the restaurant, mainly for washing dishes.

""We carried a lot of water from the owner's house to use over the weekend,"" said manager Selina Jaing. ""His house had useable water because it wasn't on the same system.""

Restaurant employees became so efficient at transporting the water over the weekend, the restaurant was still receiving 'shipments' Monday afternoon, Jaing said with a laugh.

""We're still carrying water from his house because, even though we have water, we're still not sure if we feel safe using it yet,"" she said.

West shore boil water advisory lifted, tests confirm no danger
Jeremy Arias | jarias@pennlive.com
Email the author | Follow on Twitter
'title':'West shore boil water advisory lifted, tests confirm no danger',
'desc': 'Approximately 24,000 American-Pennsylvania Water Company customers given the green light to use water without boiling first.',

A boil water advisory in place for much of the west shore since Saturday after a water leak in Silver Spring Township was lifted Monday morning after tests confirmed the water is potable.

The advisory, which impacted the townships of Silver Spring as well as Hampden, East Pennsboro and Lower Allen, was lifted by the Pennsylvania-American Water Company shortly after 6:30 a.m. Monday.

The company ran tests confirming the water is safe to drink and at acceptable bacterial levels shortly after the leak Saturday and again Sunday, according to a company press release.

The leak was reported Saturday morning on a private line near the Silver Spring Square Shopping Center off Carlisle Pike and affected nearly 24,000 customers.

Water pressure was restored to customers Sunday, but tests for bacteria take about 24 hours to run accurately, the water company indicated.

Jeremy Arias | jarias@pennlive.com
Email the author | Follow on Twitter
'title':'West shore boil water advisory lifted, tests confirm no danger',
'desc': 'Approximately 24,000 American-Pennsylvania Water Company customers given the green light to use water without boiling first.',

A boil water advisory in place for much of the west shore since Saturday after a water leak in Silver Spring Township was lifted Monday morning after tests confirmed the water is potable.

The advisory, which impacted the townships of Silver Spring as well as Hampden, East Pennsboro and Lower Allen, was lifted by the Pennsylvania-American Water Company shortly after 6:30 a.m. Monday.

The company ran tests confirming the water is safe to drink and at acceptable bacterial levels shortly after the leak Saturday and again Sunday, according to a company press release.

The leak was reported Saturday morning on a private line near the Silver Spring Square Shopping Center off Carlisle Pike and affected nearly 24,000 customers.

Water pressure was restored to customers Sunday, but tests for bacteria take about 24 hours to run accurately, the water company indicated.

column1: PLYMOUTH -- UPDATE: Service has been restored to all customers by Monday morning. The boil advisory remains until further notice.
About 6,700 Pennsylvania American Water customers are under a boil advisory after a fire hydrant broke in Luzerne County.
Firefighters and UGI crews were at West Shawnee Avenue and Nottingham Street in Plymouth Sunday morning, as the hydrant spewed water into the air.
According to Pennsylvania American Water, a tractor trailer struck the hydrant, causing low water levels in storage tanks.
Customers in Plymouth, Courtdale, Pringle, Larksville and Edwardsville should boil their water before drinking it until further notice.
Water tankers have been placed at the Courtdale municipal building and at the end of North Street in Pringle.
There is no word on how long it will take to fix the hydrant.

column1: PLYMOUTH -- UPDATE: Service has been restored to all customers by Monday morning. The boil advisory remains until further notice.
About 6,700 Pennsylvania American Water customers are under a boil advisory after a fire hydrant broke in Luzerne County.
Firefighters and UGI crews were at West Shawnee Avenue and Nottingham Street in Plymouth Sunday morning, as the hydrant spewed water into the air.
According to Pennsylvania American Water, a tractor trailer struck the hydrant, causing low water levels in storage tanks.
Customers in Plymouth, Courtdale, Pringle, Larksville and Edwardsville should boil their water before drinking it until further notice.
Water tankers have been placed at the Courtdale municipal building and at the end of North Street in Pringle.
There is no word on how long it will take to fix the hydrant.

column1: PLYMOUTH -- UPDATE: Service has been restored to all customers by Monday morning. The boil advisory remains until further notice.
About 6,700 Pennsylvania American Water customers are under a boil advisory after a fire hydrant broke in Luzerne County.
Firefighters and UGI crews were at West Shawnee Avenue and Nottingham Street in Plymouth Sunday morning, as the hydrant spewed water into the air.
According to Pennsylvania American Water, a tractor trailer struck the hydrant, causing low water levels in storage tanks.
Customers in Plymouth, Courtdale, Pringle, Larksville and Edwardsville should boil their water before drinking it until further notice.
Water tankers have been placed at the Courtdale municipal building and at the end of North Street in Pringle.
There is no word on how long it will take to fix the hydrant.

column1: A broken water main break in Cumberland County has prompted a precautionary boil-water advisory for Pennsylvania American Water customers living in the following areas:
A leak was discovered around 9 a.m. on a private service line at the Wegman’s Shopping Center on Carlisle Pike in Hampden Township, according to Pennsylvania American Water spokesman Terry Maenza.
The leak caused a significant loss of water to the Pennsylvania American Water storage tanks and a loss of water pressure.
Repairs to the service line are under way and water will be tested for any contamination, Maenza said.

Residents are advised to bring all water to a boil, letting it boil for one minute and cool before use. Boiled or bottled water should be used for drinking, making ice, brushing teeth, washing dishes, and food preparation until further notice.
All West Shore Pennsylvania American Water customers are being asked to reduce any non-essential water usage until the issue has been corrected.
A water tanker will be stationed at the Kohl’s Department Store Parking lot located at 6444 Carlisle Pike in Hampden Township. Customers are asked to bring their own containers.

column1: A broken water main break in Cumberland County has prompted a precautionary boil-water advisory for Pennsylvania American Water customers living in the following areas:
A leak was discovered around 9 a.m. on a private service line at the Wegman’s Shopping Center on Carlisle Pike in Hampden Township, according to Pennsylvania American Water spokesman Terry Maenza.
The leak caused a significant loss of water to the Pennsylvania American Water storage tanks and a loss of water pressure.
Repairs to the service line are under way and water will be tested for any contamination, Maenza said.

Residents are advised to bring all water to a boil, letting it boil for one minute and cool before use. Boiled or bottled water should be used for drinking, making ice, brushing teeth, washing dishes, and food preparation until further notice.
All West Shore Pennsylvania American Water customers are being asked to reduce any non-essential water usage until the issue has been corrected.
A water tanker will be stationed at the Kohl’s Department Store Parking lot located at 6444 Carlisle Pike in Hampden Township. Customers are asked to bring their own containers.
